Award.AwardTitle: The Motivated Origins of the Cross Race Effect

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the mechanisms underlying the Cross-Race Effect (CRE), or the tendency to more accurately recognize members of one?s own racial group compared to members of other racial groups. Despite the robustness of the CRE across experimental contexts, coming to agreement on a satisfying theoretical account for this troubling effect has proven difficult. Perhaps the longest standing explanation for the CRE is the perceptual expertise hypothesis. In essence, de facto segregation leads to individuals having no experience with cross-race faces, leading to worse recognition. Although this is certainly part of the CRE, recent evidence suggests it is not the entire story. To this end, the current research will investigate the extent to which differential motives to individuate SR and CR faces rather than differential expertise, can account for the CRE. Across 12 experiments, this proposal tests the hypothesis that inducing perceivers to individuate faces will substantially improve recognition, and alone can even account for the CRE. This research tests the hypothesis that individuation motives can be induced through a shared group membership (e.g., a same-race face, a shared university affiliation), through a targets? behavior (e.g., an individual acting in a powerful manner), or even through egocentrism (e.g., a target being similar to the self). More importantly, these individuation motives are predicted to change how faces are processed. Individuated faces (e.g., SR faces) are predicted to elicit more attention and to draw attention toward identity-diagnostic regions of the face (e.g., the eyes). Finally, directly contradicting expertise models, the motivated origins of the CRE predict that under situations where individuals are motivated to perceive ingroups as homogeneous (e.g., identity threat) should actually reduce the ostensibly highly expert SR face processing and recognition.

This targets a chronic, real-world social problem that typically disadvantages minority populations. The research outlined here will substantially graduate and undergraduate training by involving a diverse pool of graduate and undergraduate researchers. Finally, this motivated model of the CRE offers a novel means of reducing the potentially deleterious consequences of the CRE: individuation. The PI's plans to disseminate results of this research with potential real world impacts that will ultimately motivate perceivers to process information about others differently.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research was designed to investigate the Own Race Bias -- or the tendency for people to have better face recognition for own-race than for cross-race faces. This work investigated why this happens, how this happens, and what can be done to eliminate this bias (both in the lab and in the real world).  This research culminated in 10 scientific publications, as well as a number of continuing lines of research addressing exactly these questions.  In our work, we have discovered the Own Race Bias is actually a subset of an Own Group Bias.  In fact, people generally tend to recognize ingroups better than outgroups, even when those ingroups were just created in the lab (see Hugenberg et al., 2014 for a review). This tells us that its not just a lack of practice with or exposure to cross-race faces that generates this bias.  Rather, its often the result of a lack of motivation to attend to the unique, individuating characteristics of racial outgroup faces (see Young & Hugenberg, 2012).  As part of this, we have found that people often fail to process the eyes of members of outgroups.  For example, in collaboration with Kerri Kawakami's lab we (Kawakami et al. & Hugenberg, 2014) found that people tend to process the eye regions of ingroup members more than for outgroup members.  Because the eyes are so informationally rich, and so valuable in telling us about the mental states of others, this defecit in processing the eye regions of outgroup members tells us quite a lot about the Own Race Bias. People attend to the eyes of others they care about, and this eye-attention deficit appears central both in thinking about others' intentions and in encoding their faces.  Fortunately, however, this bias can be reduced and even eliminated by motivation.  Caring about the unique identities of others can go a long way toward eliminating these biases.  For example, we've found that believing that one is likely to interact more with outgroup members -- either racial outgroup members or experimentally generated outgroup members -- can be sufficient to reduce this Own Group Bias (Wilson, See, Bernstein, Hugenberg, & Chartier, 2014).

Further, this previous research has led to a number of new ideas and new questions about how we process faces.  For example, in our new research, we are beginning to investigate what makes a face seem human in the first place (it turns out, the upright orientation of a face matters a great deal).  In other work, we are investigating how people encode and remember faces of groups that they they believe have been treated fairly or cruely.  Finally, as an additional extension of this research, we have made a series of recommendations for improving eyewitness memory and the probative value of eyewitness testimony (e.g., Wilson, Hugenberg, & Bernstein, 2013).

Finally, this research has provided a wealth of professional development for students.  Five graduate students and nearly 40 undergraduates have been involved in the research, and have gotten valuable investment in the research process, including students who are often underrepresented in science (e.g., African Americans, Arab Americans, women).
